content.html: The reflections which form the subject of this little treatise date from the autumn of the year 1858... I formed the fixed resolve to reflect until I had found a purely arithmetical and completely rigorous foundation for the principles of infinitesimal analysis.

poll.question: What foundational theorem does Dedekind later show is equivalent to the principle of continuity?
options: That every polynomial has a root.
That every bounded increasing sequence has a limit.
That every rational number has a decimal expansion.

content.html: By arithmetic I understand the science of numbers... subtraction and division shall always be possible.

poll.question: Why were negative and rational numbers introduced according to Dedekind?
options: To remove the restrictions of subtraction and division.

content.html: The rational numbers form an ordered field; but they do not suffice to express every magnitude...

poll.question: What example does Dedekind later use to demonstrate this insufficiency?
options: The square root of a non-square integer.

content.html: Let D be a positive integer which is not the square of an integer... No rational number whose square equals D exists.

poll.question: Why does this example lead to a Dedekind cut without a greatest element?
options: Because rationals with square less than D have no maximum.

content.html: If all points of a straight line fall into two classes... there exists one and only one point which produces this division.

poll.question: What is remarkable about Dedekind’s treatment of this statement?
options: He declares it an axiom defining continuity.

content.html: Every cut of the rational numbers... determines either a rational or an irrational number.

poll.question: What guarantees that each cut corresponds to exactly one number?
options: The definition of equality via identical lower sets.

content.html: Whenever a cut is given which is not produced by a rational number, we create a new number...

poll.question: What philosophical stance does this reflect?
options: Numbers are created by definition, not discovered geometrically.

content.html: The totality of all real numbers forms a complete ordered field...

poll.question: Which additional property distinguishes \(\mathbb{R}\) from \(\mathbb{Q}\)?
options: Every cut of \(\mathbb{R}\) is produced by a number.

content.html: If \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\) are real numbers corresponding to cuts... their sum is defined by a corresponding cut.

poll.question: Why does Dedekind define addition via cuts rather than decimal expansions?
options: To reduce operations entirely to rational arithmetic.

content.html: The order of the real numbers is such that if \(\alpha > \beta\) and \(\beta > \gamma\), then \(\alpha > \gamma\).

poll.question: What does this ensure about the structure of \(\mathbb{R}\)?
options: It forms a totally ordered set.
